text:
Matt Davenport: So tell me a little bit about
Analytica.
What exactly is it?

Alex Scott: It's a massive instrumentation
show, which is held every other year in Munich.

This year there were more than 35,000 visitors
who went along to see the big machinery, the

instrumentation that everyone wants in their
labs.

Matt: When you travel to Analytica, how do
you get there?

Alex: I'm 45 minutes away from the U.K.'s
largest airport, that's Heathrow.

It's two hours on a flight, but it's a very
different climate.
We get lot of rain here in London.
Typically, Analytica in April is sunny.
And it didn't disappoint this time.
It was really lovely.

Matt: What were the themes at Analytica this
year that you saw?

Alex: Two years ago, when I went to Analytica,
connectivity, connecting instrumentation to
either the cloud or to a data management system.
That was happening, but it wasn't everywhere.

And now it's everywhere and everything is
connected.
I mean, even the fridges were connected.

Matt: Vendors pushing it is one thing, but
how receptive were the scientists there looking
at the equipment?

Alex: I'm not sure that they wanted everything
connected, but the pipette was certainly something
that had one of the largest interests.

There was a little company there called Gilson,
American company.

And they had an electronic pipette which is
connected to a tablet.

And basically, the pipette interacts in real
time with an app on the tablet so that you

don't need to start writing up your lab notes
afterwards about your methodology because
it's already done for you.

So there were a lot of young scientists especially
who were looking at that.

Another one which drew a lot of interest,
actually, at Analytica, was a portable, handheld

spectrometer produced by a little company
called Spectral Engines, a start-up company.

Dominik G. Rabus: So this is the future of
material scanning from Spectral Engines with
connectivity to the cloud, IoT service.
Future is here.

Alex: And they're already trialing them with
the U.S. police force to assess illegal drugs.

Maybe a few things were there a little bit
early.
There was one company called Helbling from Switzerland
and they were showing off augmented reality.

Nicole Gm√ºr: We programmed augmented reality
with a Microsoft Hololens and it can help

in the industry to train or to get used to
augmented reality.

Alex: And you can actually see your instrument
in front of you.

You can reach out and turn buttons on and
off.

So, if you were running a hazardous experiment,
you could be in the next room and use these

goggles and you could turn off and on your
instrumentation and manage the process.

So I thought that was pretty cool and that
may be something that, you know, will come

in in the future, either for these kind of
dangerous experiments or for training for
using certain equipment.
I thought that was quite an interesting one.

Matt: So which machine at Analytica had the
longest line?
Alex: That's an interesting one.

So it was hot there and I saw this long queue
of about 20 people and by the time I got to

the front, I realized it was an ice cream
machine.
Ice creams, you know.

Hey, not the most expensive machine, but definitely
the most in demand.
